Award.AwardTitle: Supporting Large Scale Change in Science Education: Understanding Professional Development and Adoption Variation Related to the Revised Advanced Placement Curriculum (PD-RAP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal leverages the re-design of the Advanced Placement (AP) curricula currently under way to study the impact of teacher professional development on student achievement in a natural experiment at scale. Researchers from the University of Massachusetts Boston, Harvard University, the University of Michigan, and the Education Development Center, Inc are conducting a quasi-experimental research study to examine the professional development experienced by AP Biology, Chemistry and Physics teachers to determines 1) the relationship between teacher and school characteristics and the professional development patterns that teachers choose; 2) the relationship between the professional development patterns that various types of teachers choose and their students' outcomes; and 3) the challenges encountered in delivering various forms of professional development at this level of scale. In addition to supporting the improvment of professional development of AP teachers by the College Board, the findings contribute to a better understanding of the relationship between professional development and student achievement more generally.

This study uses the existing context of the AP Course Audit by which all teachers of AP courses submit a syllabus, descriptions of laboratory investigations, and information regarding contact hours and the background of teachers, including the professional development programs accessed. The teachers who submit audits will be surveyed using the Stages of Concern Questionnaire together with other items to determine their perceptions of the AP Science redesign. The experiences of over 20,000 teachers are examined over the course of the study. Teachers who participate in AP professional development conducted by the College Board and the Active AP online Teacher Community (APoTC) will be surveyed about their professional development experiences. Case studies of 40 using interview, elaborated survey items, and artifacts from their teaching provide information about the quality of the teacher implementation of the AP course. Scores on the AP exams of all of the students will be linked to the teachers and the relationships among those scores and teacher professional development experiences analyzed using multi-level regression analyses.

The findings from this study have considerable importance for those individuals who provide professional development for science teachers. The results will inform the College Board and others who provide professional development directly to AP science teachers about how that support needs to change in order to more effectively support teachers. Improving the support that AP teachers receive has the potential to improve the learning experiences of the students who participate in those classes. In addition, this study will provide information about issues and challenges to providing professional development at scale to a wider audience of professional development providers. As the Next Generation Science Standards come online, this information will be useful to policy makers and practitioners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Advanced Placement (AP) Redesign by the College Board required 25,000 high school AP Science teachers to make significant changes in the content they taught and how they taught it if they expected their students to do well on the new AP science exams.  This provided an unprecedented opportunity to study teachers’ professional development (PD) choices in the context of large-scale reform when preparing to teach the revised AP Biology, Chemistry, and Physics curricula and the impact of the teachers’ PD choices on student outcomes (i.e. AP science exam scores) at scale.

We determined teachers’ PD choices and rationale for selection through teacher responses to web-based surveys, sent to all AP Biology, Chemistry and Physics teachers.  The timeframe of our research allowed us to repeat the survey for AP Biology teachers in Years 1, 2 and 3 of the redesign and for the AP Chemistry teachers in Years 1 and 2 of the redesign.  The surveys, in addition to PD choices, included questions regarding school demographics, classroom contexts, teaching strategies employed, challenges regarding implementation of the new curriculum and more.  Approximately 30% of all AP teachers completed the survey. In addition, case studies of approximately 50 teachers were conducted through longitudinal phone interviews.  Finally, the online AP Teacher Communities were studied as a unique PD choice in that the PD was bottom-up: determined and delivered by peers, rather than top-down from the College Board or a  PD provider.

Every teacher engaged in some form of PD activity. However, PD participation patterns were not consistent across teacher groups, disciplines, and/or years of the AP redesign implementation. From our survey data analysis, we found that participation in the online Advanced Placement Teacher Communities (APTC) had a small but positive significant association with student AP scores, meaning teachers who used the APTC were more likely to have students with higher AP exam scores compared to teachers who did not participate in the APTC. Moreover, the APTC provided a personalized, peer-generated, affective environment that worked well with other forms of PD in order for teachers to prepare to teach to the revised AP curriculum goals. We did not find other single PD choices (i.e. weeklong summer workshop, short face-to-face courses, and online self-paced courses, course materials/resources) to have stronger direct associations with AP scores.

Further analysis indicated that other factors such as student characteristics, teaching, and school characteristics are more influential on students’ AP science exam scores than teachers’ PD participation. For example, teachers’ perceived administrative support, self-efficacy, teaching experience, and elements of classroom instruction were positively related to student performance. We also examined students who performed better than expected on the AP Exam based on their PSAT scores and who attended schools in low-socio-economic districts. We found that increased financial resources, more days of instruction, an increase in teachers’ knowledge and experience, and informal teacher PD activities (i.e. mentoring, teacher-initiated meetings, attending conferences) were significantly positively associated with better-than-expected AP scores. These findings suggest potential levers for schools that are usually low-resourced and have teachers who are not as experienced as those in other school districts to improve students’ performance on high-stakes exams and college-preparatory courses, thereby narrowing achievement gaps and increasing overall student learning and opportunities.

The inquiry lab requirements are important components of the redesigned AP courses. Also, teachers’ PD participation was associated with the total number of labs that were conducted in their classrooms. This is notable because we also found that the number of AP labs teachers used in their instruction was associated with higher AP science scores. However, the more challenges that teachers indicated that they had with the new curriculum, the fewer labs were conducted and the fewer AP science practice elements were in their instruction.  

According to our case studies and qualitative data analysis, teachers indicated their need and/or desire to attend PD to learn about the AP Redesign. They often made their decision about which PD to attend based on the location of the PD and the cost of the PD.  We also learned that teachers whose beliefs, scientific content knowledge, and pedagogy were aligned with the reform seemed to become more comfortable with the reform more quickly than those teachers whose teaching beliefs did not. That said, all the teachers expressed some concern about the redesign as, generally, they did not feel they were given enough practice exams to prepare their students for the new exam.

Our findings offer all professional development providers with information on how to target and refine their experiences at scale for different teacher audiences and for mandated changes in curriculum. By providing better PD and support to their teachers, our findings can assist a diverse set of students in attaining higher AP scores, thereby increasing their likelihood of improving their preparation for STEM coursework in college.
